Wesley, thank you for your comments.  Indeed one of our goals is to raise=
 the profile of neuroevolution in mainstream AI venues that are not exclusi=
ve to only evolutionary computation (EC).  Of course, we still very much en=
joy and support EC venues.

I think your question on additional dimensions =
applies not only to multiagent learning, but in fact to any type of HyperNE=
AT learning application.  I do believe that additional dimensions can be pu=
t to good use.  There are many possible conceptual arrangements of problem =
geometry that could take advantage of higher dimensions.  However, the plac=
ement of sensors (or other nodes) in different geometries is a heuristic bi=
as to HyperNEAT, and it is possible in some cases that its advantage would =
be outweighed by its cost (i.e. adding many more dimensions).  Sometimes th=
ere will be ways to separate important categories even within only two or t=
hree dimensions by simply separating them within the geometry offered by th=
ose few dimensions.

The many implications of different geometrical configu=
rations for various problems remain largely unexplored, although Jeff Clune=
 has taken steps in that direction.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wes=
ley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
>
> Congratulations David, Joel, Sebastian, =
and Ken! Another top-tier AI 
> publication for neuroevolution. You guys ha=
d better slow down. :)
> 
> I'm glad to see the results confirm the intuiti=
on that I think most 
> people had. The videos are also impressive (though =
the wmv's crashed my 
> Firefox, maybe YouTube videos would be better?).
> =

> As a follow-up question, I wonder if additional dimensions would be 
> u=
seful for evolving sensors that have to deal with multiple, distinct 
> cat=
egories of objects. A simple example would be a first-person shooter, 
> wh=
ere you have walls, enemies, teammates, and projectiles all at once. 
> You=
 could separate these values via input activation levels, but would 
> it m=
ake more sense to separate each class of object into a separate 
> location=
 in a new dimesion?
> 
> Congrats again, and enjoy Toronto!
> 
> Wesley
> 
=
> Ken wrote:
> >
> > Our 2008 GECCO paper by David D'Ambrosio and myself in=
troduced the 
> > idea that a single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neu=
ral networks 
> > (instead of just one) that represent a pattern of policie=
s for an 
> > entire team. Since then a few people have asked about the way=
 we laid 
> > out the team on the substrate and whether alternatives might =
be better.
> >
> > I am happy to announce, with my co-authors David D'Ambro=
sio, Joel 
> > Lehman, and Sebastian Risi, that we have extensively tested =
such an 
> > alternative z-axis-based encoding and published the results to=
 appear 
> > in AAMAS 2010, available here:
> >
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu=
/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html 
> > <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/pub=
lications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html>
> >
> > Direct Link: http://eplex.cs=
.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf 
> > <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/=
dambrosio_aamas10.pdf>
> >
> > We believe this z-based substrate layout is =
superior to the previous 
> > one, particularly for scaling the size of the=
 team, and should open up 
> > the field of multiagent learning further to =
HyperNEAT. The paper also 
> > includes the first published results on scal=
ing the size of the team 
> > without further training, which works because=
 HyperNEAT can 
> > interpolate new policies for ANNs inserted along the z =
axis of the 
> > substrate.
> >
> > Videos that accompany the paper are her=
e:
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/mahnaamas2010.html 
> > <http://eplex.cs.ucf=
.edu/mahnaamas2010.html>
> >
> > ken
> >
> >
